Increased expression and activity of the ligand-gated ion channel <math alttext="T R P V 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>TRPV1</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> has been shown to block cell division and induce apoptosis in human cells. The structure of the <math alttext="T R P V 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>TRPV1</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> protein consists of several transmembrane domains that are embedded in the membrane as well as a carboxy-terminus and an amino-terminus that are located inside the cell (Figure 1).

Figure 1. Structure of the <math alttext="T R P V 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>TRPV1</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> protein channel in the membrane

<math alttext="T R P V 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>TRPV1</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is activated by several stimuli, including the binding of capsaicin, a chemical found in chili peppers. Capsaicin enters the cell by simple diffusion and then binds to one of the transmembrane domains of <math alttext="T R P V 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>TRPV1</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, which opens the ion channel.

The opening of the <math alttext="T R P V 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>TRPV1</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> channel allows <math alttext="C a with a plus two charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Ca</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> ions to enter the cell, leading to the activation of the enzyme calcineurin. Calcineurin removes phosphate groups from the phosphorylated form of the transcription factor <math alttext="N F A T 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NFAT2</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, which is typically found in the cytoplasm. Once dephosphorylated, <math alttext="N F A T 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NFAT2</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> moves into the nucleus, where it blocks the transcription of another protein, <math alttext="A T F 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ATF3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. <math alttext="A T F 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ATF3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, when active, prevents the cell cycle regulatory protein <math alttext="p G o G" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pGoG</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> from inducing apoptosis and blocking cell division (Figure 2).

Figure 2. Capsaicin-activated <math alttext="T R P V 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>TRPV1</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> signaling pathway in human cells

(a) Describe the characteristics of capsaicin that allow it to enter the cell before binding to a transmembrane domain of <math alttext="T R P V 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>TRPV1</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> . Describe what prevents <math alttext="N F A T 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NFAT2</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> from inhibiting <math alttext="A T F 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ATF3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> expression in the absence of calcineurin.
